The day after the presidential runoff election, during which Rodrigo Paz won 54.5% of the vote, signaling a major political realignment in Bolivia.

keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz has won Bolivia’s presidential runoff, becoming the country’s first conservative leader in over two decades, signaling a significant shift from decades of leftist governance under the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party.
Paz pledged to rebuild ties with the United States, particularly with the Trump administration, and to attract foreign investment, reversing years of isolation and strained relations with Washington.
Paz rejected an IMF bailout, citing public resentment toward international financial institutions under leftist rule, and instead focused on domestic economic reform and targeted subsidies.

Paz and his running mate Edman Lara, a former police captain turned social media activist, won support by appealing to working-class and rural voters, particularly those disillusioned with corruption and elite rule.

Despite promises of fuel imports and economic revitalization, Bolivia faces a severe economic crisis — including fuel shortages, high inflation (23% in September), and a depleted foreign exchange reserve — requiring immediate fiscal restructuring.

Paz plans to clean up Bolivia’s institutions, including the judiciary, which has been seen as politically biased under MAS rule, while promising to protect Indigenous rights and political representation.

The election has triggered protests, particularly from supporters of former President Jorge Quiroga, who allege electoral fraud, reflecting deep public distrust in Bolivia’s electoral system, especially after Morales’ disputed 2019 reelection.

Paz's economic team has approved a $3.5 billion loan and is working on a $600 million plan to balance the budget, with a focus on targeted cash transfers to poor families instead of universal fuel subsidies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, Bolivia’s first conservative president-elect in over two decades, won the presidential runoff with 54.5% of the vote, signaling a decisive end to decades of leftist rule under the Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) party. In a significant shift, Paz pledged to rebuild relations with the United States, particularly the Trump administration, and to attract foreign investment, reversing years of isolation and antipathy toward U.S. policy. He rejected an IMF bailout due to public resentment toward international financial institutions, instead focusing on targeted economic reforms such as direct cash transfers to poor families and ending universal fuel subsidies. His running mate, Edman Lara, a former police captain and social media activist, helped mobilize working-class and rural voters by denouncing corruption. Despite promises, Bolivia faces severe economic challenges including fuel shortages, high inflation (23% in September), and a depleted foreign exchange reserve. Paz emphasized that his priority is 'putting the house in order' — including reforming the judiciary and restoring faith in institutions — before pursuing foreign investment. This shift is also reflected in his outreach to Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado, signaling a break from Venezuela’s repressive regime. The election has triggered protests from Quiroga supporters, who allege fraud and express distrust in Bolivia’s electoral system, highlighting the fragility of political legitimacy in the face of deep societal divisions.
title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Presidential Runoff, Becomes Bolivia’s First Conservative Leader in Decades
